title: Pru (album)
text:
Pru is the debut studio album by American singer <a href="Prudencesa%20Renfro">Pru</a>. It was released on November 7, 2000, through <a href="Capitol%20Records">Capitol Records</a>. "Pru" was managed by Capitol Records executive Roy Lott, who had signed Pru to <a href="Warner/Chappell%20Music">Warner/Chappell Music Publishing</a> after being impressed by her songwriting and voice on a <a href="demo%20tape">demo tape</a>. Pru collaborated with Ben Garrison, the Characters, and Rick Williams on the album.
According to Lott, Pru was part of Capitol Records' attempts to attract a wider audience through her <a href="Crossover%20music">crossover appeal</a>. According to <a href="Music%20criticism">music critics</a>, the album encompasses several genres, with some commentators noting influences from <a href="neo%20soul">neo soul</a>. Pru also used poetry as an inspiration for writing music.
Reviews of the album were generally positive, singling out in particular its composition and Pru's voice. They also compared her favorably to contemporary artists. The album peaked at number 176 on the <a href="Billboard%20200">"Billboard" 200</a> chart, an achievement made possible in part by an intensive marketing strategy devised by Capitol Records executives. Two singles"Candles" and "Aaroma (of a Man)" were released to positive reviews. "Candles" peaked at number 68 on the <a href="Hot%20R%26amp%3BB/Hip-Hop%20Songs">Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs</a> <a href="Billboard%20%28magazine%29">"Billboard"</a> chart.
Background and recording.
American singer <a href="Prudencesa%20Renfro">Prudencesa Renfro</a>, professionally known as Pru, was signed through <a href="Warner/Chappell%20Music">Warner/Chappell Music Publishing</a> by <a href="Capitol%20Records">Capitol Records</a>' executive Roy Lott, who said that he was "drawn to" her songwriting and voice. Jack Ponti, of Cazzy Dog Management, had helped Pru produce a <a href="demo%20tape">demo tape</a> to secure the record deal. Lott had noted Pru's potential as an artist through her lyrics. He worked closely with her to match her songwriting to the most appropriate sound, serving as the executive producer for her debut studio album "Pru".
Prior to securing a record deal, Pru had found inspiration for her music in artists such as <a href="Cassandra%20Wilson">Cassandra Wilson</a> and <a href="Dianne%20Reeves">Dianne Reeves</a>. She wrote song lyrics and poetry while attending high school and then <a href="Texas%20Southern%20University">Texas Southern University</a>, coupling her lyrics with the music of other artists such as <a href="Michael%20Jackson">Michael Jackson</a>, <a href="Rachelle%20Ferrell">Rachelle Ferrell</a>, <a href="Sade%20%28band%29">Sade</a>, <a href="Naughty%20by%20Nature">Naughty by Nature</a>, <a href="the%20Isley%20Brothers">the Isley Brothers</a>, and <a href="Miles%20Davis">Miles Davis</a>. While discussing her approach to songwriting, Pru elaborated: "From a word, I can get a whole picture, a visual. The song becomes a poem, almost like a thesis." She considered her music as a form of poetry, citing the album track "Hazy Shades" as an example of a poem turned into a song.
Pru stated that she wanted her songs to bring variety to <a href="contemporary%20R%26amp%3BB">contemporary R&B</a>, and described the material as the opposite of the formulaic music typically found on radio. On her official website, the singer identified her style as connected with the soul. Though <a href="AllMusic">AllMusic</a> gives the singer songwriting credit on twelve of the tracks, Pru is only credited for co-writing "Aaroma" on the album's liner notes. The record was completed at Studio57 and Weight Room in New York City, with <a href="Audio%20mixing%20%28recorded%20music%29">mixing</a> handled by <a href="Mike%20Shipley">Mike Shipley</a> and <a href="Tony%20Maserati">Tony Maserati</a>. Following release of the album, Pru spoke highly of her experiences with the producers and felt that they "la[id] a good bed around the lyrics and the melodies".
Composition and sound.
"Pru" comprises thirteen songs, among which <a href="Music%20criticism">music critics</a> identified several different musical genres. "<a href="Tucson%20Weekly">Tucson Weekly</a>"'s Margaret Regan wrote that Pru's material was an example of <a href="New%20Age%20music">new age music</a>, while Janine Coveney of "<a href="Billboard%20%28magazine%29">Billboard</a>" called the singer's sound as "alterna-soul/pop music". AllMusic's Ed Hogan noted that the songs combined <a href="hip%20hop%20music">hip hop</a>, <a href="Latin%20music%20%28genre%29">Latin music</a>, contemporary R&B, <a href="rock%20music">rock</a>, and <a href="trip%20hop">trip hop</a>.
Pru called the opening track, "Prophecy of a Flower", the album's focal point, saying that "everything else falls a little to the left and to the right of that". The R&B and <a href="Soul%20music">soul</a> song's lyrics incorporate words from the <a href="he%20loves%20me...%20he%20loves%20me%20not">he loves me... he loves me not</a> game. The second track, "183 Miles", combines hip hop and <a href="country%20music">country music</a>, its lyrics revolving around a love story. Sampling <a href="the%20Miracles">the Miracles</a>' 1965 song "<a href="The%20Tracks%20of%20My%20Tears">The Tracks of My Tears</a>", "Candles" is a "midtempo <a href="Groove%20%28music%29">groove</a>" that features the titular object, candles, as a metaphor for "stress (burned at both ends) and healing (lit for meditation)". The Miracles' single was a direct inspiration for the lyrics and instrumentation on the track. Hogan, however, saw "Candles" as diverging from the song's message.
Coveney described "Aaroma", the fourth track, as offering a "sexy challenge" to the listener. Pru adapted one of the song's lyrics, "If a man came my way and I didn't doubt him", from one of her poems. While discussing the meaning of the title, the singer said it derived from an "old <a href="Southern%20United%20States">southern</a> saying: 'I could smell you coming'". "Hazy Shade" is a <a href="ballad">ballad</a> that Hogan described as "recall[ing] 'blue light in the basement' old skool <a href="slow%20jam">slow jam</a>s". Preceded by "Salsa Interlude", Pru's cover of Sade's 1984 single "<a href="Smooth%20Operator">Smooth Operator</a>" features a stronger Latin-inspired instrumental than the original. Hogan noted that the song included "popping percussion and fluttery flute runs". The ending of the ninth track, "Can't Compare Your Love", takes inspiration from <a href="spoken%20word">spoken word</a> performances, and the following song ,"Sketches of Pain", deliberately plays with the title of <a href="Miles%20Davis">Miles Davis</a>' 1960 album "<a href="Sketches%20of%20Spain">Sketches of Spain</a>". Colin Ross of "<a href="PopMatters">PopMatters</a>" described the twelfth track, "What They Gone Do?", as featuring a "brassy <a href="Two-step%20%28dance%20move%29">two-step</a>" in its instrumentation.
Release and promotion.
On August 19, 2000, "Pru" was first announced as an untitled album scheduled for release the following month. Pushed back to October 24, 2000, the album was developed under the working title "Inside A Poem"a reference to Pru's poetic style of songwriting. Retitled "Pru", Capitol Records released the record on November 7, 2000, as an <a href="Compact%20disc">audio CD</a>, <a href="Compact%20Cassette">cassette</a>, and <a href="Music%20download">digital download</a>. It was also made available as an "enhanced audio CD", which contains <a href="multimedia">multimedia</a> computer files and a video entitled "In the Life of Pru". "Pru" reached a peak position of number 176 on the <a href="Billboard%20200">"Billboard" 200</a>, spending two weeks on the chart, and peaked on "Billboard's" <a href="Top%20R%26amp%3BB/Hip-Hop%20Albums">R&B Albums</a> at number 38, leaving the chart after thirty-two weeks.
Prior to the album's release, Pru performed with a band that included members of <a href="the%20Family%20Stand">the Family Stand</a> at the Los Angeles venue Luna Park and the New York City club S.O.B. She sang later in Chicago, Houston, and Atlanta to promote the album further. Pru also toured with the Family Stand and members of Sade. While discussing the album's promotion, Linton said: "Pru is a live performance artist and, being new, we wanted people to get their first impression of her in that environment".
According to "Billboard" magazine, Capitol Records had placed significant focus on the marketing for the album, including the release of an electronic press kit and promotion through "non-retail accounts". Lott told "Billboard" magazine that Pru would act as a primary part of Capitol Records' attempt to attract a wider audience with her <a href="Crossover%20music">crossover appeal</a>. David Linton, Capitol Records' senior vice president of R&B promotion and marketing, identified R&B, <a href="adult%20contemporary%20music">adult contemporary music</a>, and <a href="Top%2040">top 40 music</a> as potential markets for the singer.
Singles.
Released as the lead single from "Pru", "Candles" was sent to <a href="Rhythmic%20contemporary">rhythmic</a> radio stations in the United States during the first week of September. Lott said the song was chosen as Pru's debut single as he felt that its allusions to the Miracles' song would appeal to listeners of all ages. It was further promoted by its inclusion on a back-to-school CD sampler from retailer <a href="Delia%27s">Delia's</a>. Director <a href="Dave%20Meyers%20%28director%29">Dave Meyers</a> shot the accompanying <a href="music%20video">music video</a>, which was released on November 25, 2000. The video premiered on <a href="MTV">MTV</a> in February 2001, following roughly two months of rotation on <a href="BET">BET</a>. "Candles" reached number 68 on the <a href="Hot%20R%26amp%3BB/Hip-Hop%20Songs">Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs</a> "Billboard" chart where it spent fourteen weeks, and peaked at number 65 on the <a href="R%26amp%3BB/Hip-Hop%20Airplay">R&B/Hip-Hop Airplay</a> "Billboard" chart where it spent ten weeks. For both chart appearances, "Billboard" credited the song as appearing on "The Sound of Style: Capital Records Fall 2000 Collection". Critical response to "Candles" was positive. David Dickinson, a music director at <a href="WHUR-FM">WHUR-FM</a>, felt the single would be appropriate for radio and praised its production and Pru's voice. A writer from "Billboard" magazine complimented the lyrics and Pru's vocal performance, contrasting the artist's "cool, literate sensibility [against] the blatant sexual overtones" from other contemporary R&B female singers, but expressed doubt that hip-hop and mainstream R&B stations would play the song, seeing it as better suited for adult R&B radio.
"Aaroma" was released as the album's second single under the modified title "Aaroma (of a Man)". A writer from "Billboard" magazine compared its lyrics positively to those in <a href="Toni%20Braxton">Toni Braxton</a>'s "<a href="Un-Break%20My%20Heart">Un-Break My Heart</a>" (1996). Another reviewer from the same publication singled out the track as one of the best from the album. According to a "Billboard" article published on June 16, 2001, <a href="Dance%20music">dance</a> and R&B remixes of the song were commissioned from Hani al-Badir and Carlos "Six July" Broady, respectively; the remixes were scheduled to be added to a re-release of the album. A music video for the single was filmed in June 2001. The song was also featured on the <a href="EMI">EMI</a>-released album "Celebrating Black Music Sampler 2001". Along with the two singles "Candles" and "Aaroma (of a Man)", the record was promoted as featuring "Smooth Operator" and "183 Miles".
Critical reception.
Upon its release, "Pru" received positive feedback from music critics. Ed Hogan praised Pru's experimentation with musical genres. In discussing its many influences, Colin Ross wrote that the album never sounded uneven or disjointed. He commended the singer for communicating a range of emotions, by turns seeming "innocent, self-assured, uncertain, elated and vulnerable", praising in particular the album's instrumentation and lyrics. A "Billboard" writer described "Pru" as "sparkl[ing] with colorfully imaged songs about love won, lost and anticipated". "<a href="USA%20Today">USA Today</a>"s Steve Jones praised the performer for the "remarkable depth in her poetics about joy and heartbreak". Jones wrote that the album demonstrated that Pru had a clear sense of what she wanted to achieve for her career and sound. <a href="Ebony%20%28magazine%29">"Ebony"</a>s Lynn Norment described her as possessing a "rich, earthy voice and lyrical talent", responding positively to the artist's influences from scripture and poetry. A writer for "<a href="Sister%202%20Sister">Sister 2 Sister</a>" commended Pru for her ability to convey emotion to the listener, and identified "Prophecy of a Flower" as their favorite track from the album. The "<a href="Houston%20Press">Houston Press</a>"' Craig D. Lindsey praised Pru's music and live performances, describing her songs as "soulful, earthy and organic" and the antithesis to music such as <a href="Destiny%27s%20Child">Destiny's Child</a>'s 1999 single "<a href="Bills%2C%20Bills%2C%20Bills">Bills, Bills, Bills</a>". The album was called "[a]rtful ... stunning ... sexy" by a reviewer from "<a href="People%20%28magazine%29">People</a>".
Several media outlets compared Pru to other artists, with a "Billboard" reviewer attributing the singer as writing in the same style as contemporary neo soul performers. The singer's voice was compared to <a href="Lauryn%20Hill">Lauryn Hill</a>, <a href="Macy%20Gray">Macy Gray</a>, and <a href="Erykah%20Badu">Erykah Badu</a> by AllMusic's Stacia Proefrock. She was classified as part of an "emerging school of poetics" by Ross, who said that she was "subtly changing the landscape of contemporary R&B lyricism". A "Billboard" reviewer also placed the singer as a member of "the new soul movement", and compared her work to that of <a href="Angie%20Stone">Angie Stone</a>, <a href="Amel%20Larrieux">Amel Larrieux</a>, <a href="Jill%20Scott">Jill Scott</a>, and Badu. A writer from the journal "Today's Black Woman" saw Pru as part of the neo soul genre along with Badu and Scott, saying that these singers incorporated in their music "traditional R&B as well as its new millennium, hip-hop inspired modern counterpart". Pru responded positively to the comparisons, saying: "What I think is being classified as the neo-soul classic movement has artists that are individually different in their own right, but aren't different from modern R&B."
Track listing.
Credits adapted from the liner notes of "Pru". All tracks are produced by Ben Garrison, the Characters, Pru, and Rick Williams.
Personnel.
Credits adapted from the liner notes of "Pru" and AllMusic.
